when_to_say: Used as a general greeting or to express peace.
example: السلام عليكم (As-salaam alaikum) means 'Peace be upon you.'

when_to_say: Used to greet someone informally.
example: مرحبا يا صديقي (Marhaba ya sadeeqi) means 'Hello, my friend.'

when_to_say: Used to express gratitude.
example: شكرا جزيلا (Shukran jazeelan) means 'Thank you very much.'

when_to_say: Used to ask about someone's well-being.
example: كيف حالك اليوم؟ (Kaifa halak alyawm?) means 'How are you today?'

when_to_say: Used to welcome someone to a place.
example: أهلا وسهلا بك في بيتي (Ahlan wa sahlan bik fee baytee) means 'Welcome to my house.'

when_to_say: Used to bid farewell.
example: مع السلامة، أراك قريبا (Maa as-salaama, araka qareeban) means 'Goodbye, see you soon.'

when_to_say: Used when referring to someone's name.
example: ما اسمك؟ (Maa ismuk?) means 'What is your name?'

when_to_say: Used to affirm or agree.
example: نعم، أنا بخير (Na'am, ana bekhayr) means 'Yes, I am fine.'

when_to_say: Used to deny or disagree.
example: لا، هذا ليس صحيحا (Laa, hatha laysa saheehan) means 'No, this is not correct.'

when_to_say: Used when referring to meals or eating.
example: الطعام لذيذ (At-ta'aam lazeez) means 'The food is delicious.'

when_to_say: Used to refer to any written or printed work.
example: هذا كتاب جيد (Hatha kitaab jayed) means 'This is a good book.'

when_to_say: Used to refer to educational institutions.
example: أنا أذهب إلى المدرسة (Ana adhhab ila al-madrasah) means 'I go to school.'

when_to_say: Used to refer to writing tools.
example: أريد قلم لكتابة (Ureed qalam lekitabah) means 'I need a pen to write.'

when_to_say: Used to refer to educators.
example: المعلم يشرح الدرس (Al-mu'allim yashrah ad-dars) means 'The teacher explains the lesson.'

when_to_say: Used to refer to someone learning in an institution.
example: الطالب يدرس جيدا (At-taalib yadrus jayedan) means 'The student studies well.'

when_to_say: Used to talk about periods or moments.
example: ليس لدي وقت (Laysa ladayya waqt) means 'I don't have time.'

when_to_say: Used to describe something pleasing to the senses.
example: السماء جميلة (As-sama' jameelah) means 'The sky is beautiful.'

when_to_say: Used to refer to urban areas.
example: أنا أعيش في مدينة كبيرة (Ana a'eesh fee madeenah kabeerah) means 'I live in a big city.'

when_to_say: Used to refer to medical professionals.
example: الطبيب يعالج المرضى (At-tabeeb yu'alij al-marda) means 'The doctor treats patients.'

when_to_say: Used to refer to furniture.
example: الكتب على الطاولة (Al-kutub 'ala at-taawilah) means 'The books are on the table.'

when_to_say: Used to refer to a place where people live.
example: هذا بيت كبير (Hatha bayt kabeer) means 'This is a big house.'

when_to_say: Used to refer to an opening in a wall for light and air.
example: النافذة مفتوحة (An-naafidhah maftoohah) means 'The window is open.'

when_to_say: Used to refer to an entrance or exit of a room or building.
example: الباب مغلق (Al-baab mughlaq) means 'The door is closed.'

when_to_say: Used to describe a plant with a woody trunk.
example: تحت الشجرة ظل (Tahta ash-shajarah dhil) means 'There is shade under the tree.'

when_to_say: Used to describe the heavens or the atmosphere.
example: السماء زرقاء (As-sama' zarqaa') means 'The sky is blue.'

when_to_say: Used to describe the Earth's natural satellite.
example: القمر جميل الليلة (Al-qamar jameel al-laylah) means 'The moon is beautiful tonight.'

when_to_say: Used to describe the star at the center of the solar system.
example: الشمس مشرقة (Ash-shams mushriqah) means 'The sun is shining.'

when_to_say: Used to describe a large body of saltwater.
example: أنا أحب البحر (Ana uhibb al-bahr) means 'I love the sea.'

when_to_say: Used to refer to a large natural elevation of the Earth's surface.
example: الجبل مرتفع جدا (Al-jabal murtafi' jiddan) means 'The mountain is very high.'

when_to_say: Used to describe a flowing body of freshwater.
example: النهر عميق (An-nahr 'ameeq) means 'The river is deep.'

when_to_say: Used when referring to a written or printed work.
example: أقرأ كتاباً جديداً (Aqra' kitaaban jadeedan) means 'I am reading a new book.'

when_to_say: Used when referring to a writing instrument.
example: أكتب بالقلم (Aktub bil-qalam) means 'I write with the pen.'

when_to_say: Used when referring to an institution for education.
example: أذهب إلى المدرسة (Adhhab ila al-madrasa) means 'I go to school.'

when_to_say: Used to describe someone learning at an educational institution.
example: الطالب يدرس بجد (At-talib yadrus bijid) means 'The student studies hard.'

when_to_say: Used to describe someone teaching students.
example: المعلم يشرح الدرس (Al-mu'allim yashrah ad-dars) means 'The teacher explains the lesson.'

when_to_say: Used when referring to a board for writing during lessons.
example: المعلم يكتب على السبورة (Al-mu'allim yaktub 'ala as-saboorah) means 'The teacher writes on the blackboard.'

when_to_say: Used when referring to a single unit of teaching.
example: الدرس ممتع جداً (Ad-dars mumti' jiddan) means 'The lesson is very enjoyable.'

when_to_say: Used to describe a room where teaching happens.
example: الفصل مزدحم بالطلاب (Al-fasl muzdahem bit-tullab) means 'The classroom is crowded with students.'

when_to_say: Used to describe a container for carrying books and items.
example: الحقيبة ثقيلة جداً (Al-haqibah thaqilah jiddan) means 'The bag is very heavy.'

when_to_say: Used to describe a test or assessment.
example: الامتحان كان صعباً (Al-imtihan kana sa'ban) means 'The exam was difficult.'

when_to_say: Used when referring to any type of food or meal.
example: أحب الطعام العربي (Uhibbu at-ta'aam al-arabi) means 'I love Arabic food.'

when_to_say: Used when referring to beverages.
example: أشرب الماء كل يوم (Ashrab al-ma' kulla yawm) means 'I drink water every day.'

when_to_say: Used to refer to the fruit apple.
example: أحب أكل التفاح (Uhibbu akl at-tuffah) means 'I like eating apples.'

when_to_say: Used to refer to baked goods like bread.
example: أريد خبزاً طازجاً (Ureed khubzan tazajan) means 'I want fresh bread.'

when_to_say: Used when talking about various types of meat.
example: اللحم مشوي لذيذ (Al-lahm mashwi latheeth) means 'The grilled meat is delicious.'

when_to_say: Used when referring to drinking water.
example: الماء ضروري للحياة (Al-ma' daroori lil-hayah) means 'Water is essential for life.'

when_to_say: Used when referring to a dish or plate.
example: الطبق مليء بالطعام (At-tabaq malee' bil-ta'aam) means 'The plate is full of food.'

when_to_say: Used when referring to tea as a beverage.
example: أشرب الشاي في الصباح (Ashrab ash-shai fi as-sabah) means 'I drink tea in the morning.'

when_to_say: Used when referring to the seasoning salt.
example: أضيف الملح إلى الطعام (Adeef al-milh ila at-ta'aam) means 'I add salt to the food.'

when_to_say: Used when referring to the spice or vegetable pepper.
example: أحب الفلفل الحار (Uhibbu al-filfil al-har) means 'I like spicy pepper.'

when_to_say: Used when referring to any type of book.
example: أحب قراءة الكتب (Uhibbu qira'at al-kutub) means 'I love reading books.'

when_to_say: Used when talking about writing tools.
example: أحتاج إلى قلم جديد (Ahtaj ila qalam jadeed) means 'I need a new pen.'

when_to_say: Used to refer to an educational institution.
example: المدرسة تبدأ الساعة الثامنة (Al-madrasah tabda' as-sa'ah ath-thaminah) means 'The school starts at 8 o'clock.'

when_to_say: Used to describe an educator or instructor.
example: المعلم يشرح الدرس (Al-mu'allim yashrah ad-dars) means 'The teacher explains the lesson.'

when_to_say: Used to refer to someone studying.
example: الطالب يدرس بجد (At-talib yadrus bijid) means 'The student studies hard.'

when_to_say: Used to refer to a physical classroom or grade.
example: الصف مليء بالطلاب (As-saff malee' bil-tullab) means 'The classroom is full of students.'

when_to_say: Used when talking about tests or assessments.
example: لدي اختبار غداً (Ladee ikhtibar ghadan) means 'I have an exam tomorrow.'

when_to_say: Used when referring to a specific teaching session.
example: الدرس اليوم كان مفيداً (Ad-dars al-yawm kana mufidan) means 'Today's lesson was helpful.'

when_to_say: Used to describe a piece of furniture for sitting.
example: الكرسي مريح (Al-kursi murih) means 'The chair is comfortable.'

when_to_say: Used to refer to the board used in classrooms.
example: المعلم يكتب على السبورة (Al-mu'allim yaktub ala as-sabbura) means 'The teacher writes on the blackboard.'

when_to_say: Used when referring to a piece of furniture for placing items.
example: الطاولة مليئة بالكتب (At-tawila malee'ah bil-kutub) means 'The table is full of books.'

when_to_say: Used to describe an opening in a wall for ventilation or light.
example: أفتح النافذة للهواء (Aftah an-nafitha lil-hawa) means 'I open the window for air.'

when_to_say: Used to describe an entry or exit point of a room or building.
example: الباب مفتوح (Al-bab maftuh) means 'The door is open.'

when_to_say: Used when talking about outdoor green spaces.
example: أحب المشي في الحديقة (Uhibbu al-mashi fil-hadiqa) means 'I love walking in the garden.'

when_to_say: Used to refer to roads in a city or town.
example: الشارع مزدحم اليوم (Ash-shari' muzdahem al-yawm) means 'The street is crowded today.'

when_to_say: Used to refer to the room where food is prepared.
example: أمي تطبخ في المطبخ (Ummi tatbukh fil-matbakh) means 'My mother is cooking in the kitchen.'

when_to_say: Used to refer to the place for personal hygiene.
example: الحمام نظيف (Al-hammam natheef) means 'The bathroom is clean.'

when_to_say: Used to refer to any room in a building.
example: غرفتي صغيرة (Ghurfatee sagheera) means 'My room is small.'

when_to_say: Used when referring to a piece of furniture for sleeping.
example: أنام على السرير (Anam ala as-sareer) means 'I sleep on the bed.'

when_to_say: Used when referring to a table for work or study.
example: الكتب على المكتب (Al-kutub ala al-maktab) means 'The books are on the desk.'

when_to_say: Used when referring to a vehicle.
example: السيارة حمراء (As-sayara hamra') means 'The car is red.'

when_to_say: Used to talk about air travel.
example: الطائرة كبيرة جدًا (At-ta'ira kabira jiddan) means 'The airplane is very big.'

when_to_say: Used when referring to two-wheeled transportation.
example: أحب ركوب الدراجة (Uhibbu rukub ad-diraja) means 'I love riding the bicycle.'

when_to_say: Used when talking about rail travel.
example: القطار سريع جدًا (Al-qitar saree' jiddan) means 'The train is very fast.'

when_to_say: Used to refer to the location for air travel.
example: أنتظر في المطار (Antazir fil-matar) means 'I am waiting at the airport.'

when_to_say: Used to talk about public transport.
example: الحافلة مزدحمة اليوم (Al-hafila muzdahema al-yawm) means 'The bus is crowded today.'

when_to_say: Used to describe large or central roads.
example: أعيش بجانب الشارع الرئيسي (A'eish bijanib ash-shari' ra'isi) means 'I live next to the main road.'

when_to_say: Used when talking about traffic signals.
example: الإشارة حمراء الآن (Al-ishara hamra' al-aan) means 'The light is red now.'

when_to_say: Used when referring to locations where ships dock.
example: السفينة وصلت إلى الميناء (As-safina wasalat ila al-mina') means 'The ship has arrived at the port.'

when_to_say: Used to refer to a bus, train, or other transit station.
example: أنا في المحطة الآن (Ana fil-mahatta al-aan) means 'I am at the station now.'

when_to_say: Used to talk about places of learning.
example: الطلاب يذهبون إلى المدرسة (At-tullab yadhhabuna ila al-madrasah) means 'The students go to school.'

when_to_say: Used to refer to higher education institutions.
example: أدرس في الجامعة (Adrusu fil-jami'a) means 'I study at the university.'

when_to_say: Used when referring to reading or studying materials.
example: هذا الكتاب ممتع جدًا (Hatha al-kitab mumti' jiddan) means 'This book is very interesting.'

when_to_say: Used when talking about educators.
example: المعلم يشرح الدرس (Al-mu'allim yashrah ad-dars) means 'The teacher explains the lesson.'

when_to_say: Used to describe someone who is learning.
example: الطالب يكتب الواجب (At-talib yaktub al-wajib) means 'The student writes the homework.'

when_to_say: Used to refer to educational sessions.
example: الدرس اليوم كان سهلًا (Ad-dars al-yawm kan sahlan) means 'The lesson today was easy.'

when_to_say: Used when talking about writing tools.
example: أكتب بالقلم (Aktub bil-qalam) means 'I write with the pen.'

when_to_say: Used to talk about teaching tools in classrooms.
example: المعلم يكتب على السبورة (Al-mu'allim yaktub 'ala as-saboora) means 'The teacher writes on the blackboard.'

when_to_say: Used to talk about evaluations or tests.
example: الاختبار كان صعبًا (Al-ikhtibar kan sa'ban) means 'The exam was difficult.'

when_to_say: Used when referring to places where books are stored.
example: أحب قراءة الكتب في المكتبة (Uhibbu qira'at al-kutub fil-maktaba) means 'I love reading books in the library.'

when_to_say: Used when talking about things to eat.
example: أحب تناول الطعام (Uhibbu tanaawul at-ta'am) means 'I like eating food.'

when_to_say: Used when referring to liquids or beverages.
example: أريد شرابًا باردًا (Ureedu sharaban baaridan) means 'I want a cold drink.'

when_to_say: Used when talking about plant-based foods.
example: أحب أكل الخضار (Uhibbu akl al-khodar) means 'I like eating vegetables.'

when_to_say: Used when referring to fruits.
example: أحب تناول الفاكهة (Uhibbu tanaawul al-fakihah) means 'I love eating fruit.'

when_to_say: Used when referring to animal meat.
example: أريد لحمًا مشويًا (Ureedu lahman mashwiyan) means 'I want grilled meat.'

when_to_say: Used when referring to bread.
example: أريد خبزًا طازجًا (Ureedu khobzan taazijan) means 'I want fresh bread.'

when_to_say: Used when referring to water.
example: أحتاج إلى ماء (Ahtaaj ila ma'a) means 'I need water.'

when_to_say: Used when referring to fruit juices.
example: أريد عصير البرتقال (Ureedu 'aseer al-burtuqaal) means 'I want orange juice.'

when_to_say: Used when talking about tea.
example: أحب شرب الشاي (Uhibbu shurb ash-shaay) means 'I love drinking tea.'

when_to_say: Used when referring to coffee.
example: أريد كوبًا من القهوة (Ureedu koobaan min al-qahwa) means 'I want a cup of coffee.'
